{{TennisEventInfo|1999|Estoril Open| | main_name=Portugal Open{{!}}Estoril Open | date=April 5–12, 1999 | edition=10th (men) / 3rd (women) | location=[[Oeiras Municipality, Portugal|Oeiras Municipality]], [[Portugal]] | surface=Clay / Outdoor | champms={{flagicon|ESP}} [[Albert Costa]] | champws={{flagicon|SLO}} [[Katarina Srebotnik]] | champmd={{flagicon|ESP}} [[Tomás Carbonell]] / {{flagicon|USA}} [[Donald Johnson]] | champwd={{nowrap|{{flagicon|ESP}} [[Alicia Ortuño]] / {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Cristina Torrens Valero]]}} }}
The '''1999 Estoril Open''' was a [[tennis]] tournament played on [[Clay court|outdoor clay courts]] at the [[Estoril Court Central]] in the [[Oeiras Municipality, Portugal|Oeiras Municipality]] in [[Portugal]] that was part of the [[ATP International Series|International Series]] of the [[1999 ATP Tour]] and of [[WTA Tier IV tournaments|Tier IVa]] of the [[1999 WTA Tour]]. The tournament was held from April 5–12, 1999.
==WTA Entrants== ===Seeds=== {|class="sortable wikitable" |- ! width="70"| Country ! width="175"| Player ! Rank ! Seed |- |{{flag|GER}} |[[Anke Huber]] |28 |1 |- |{{flag|FRA}} |[[Sarah Pitkowski]] |41 |2 |- |{{flag|LUX}} |[[Anne Kremer]] |43 |3 |- |{{flag|GER}} |[[Elena Pampoulova|Elena Wagner]] |83 |4 |- |{{flag|CRO}} |[[Silvija Talaja]] |79 |5 |- |{{flag|BLR}} |[[Olga Barabanschikova]] |72 |6 |- |{{flag|ITA}} |[[Laura Golarsa]] |89 |7 |- |{{flag|NED}} |[[Seda Noorlander]] |93 |8 |}
===Other entrants=== The following players received wildcards into the singles main draw: *{{flagicon|POR}} [[Ana Catarina Nogueira]] *{{flagicon|BRA}} [[Vanessa Menga]]
The following players received wildcards into the doubles main draw: *{{flagicon|POR}} [[Angela Cardoso (tennis)|Angela Cardoso]] / {{flagicon|POR}} [[Cristina Correia]]
The following players received entry from the singles qualifying draw: *{{flagicon|GER}} [[Anca Barna]] *{{flagicon|BEL}} [[Laurence Courtois]] *{{flagicon|ESP}} [[Cristina Torrens Valero]] *{{flagicon|HUN}} [[Anna Földényi]]
The following players received entry as a lucky loser: *{{flagicon|ESP}} [[Eva Bes Ostariz]] *{{flagicon|BUL}} [[Lubomira Bacheva]]
The following player received entry from the doubles qualifying draw: *{{flagicon|IND}} [[Nirupama Vaidyanathan]] / {{flagicon|ROU}} [[Andreea Ehritt-Vanc|Andreea Vanc]]
==Champions== ===Men's Singles=== {{main|1999 Estoril Open – Men's Singles}} {{flagicon|ESP}} '''[[Albert Costa]]''' defeated {{flagicon|USA}} [[Todd Martin]], 7–6<sup>(7–4)</sup>, 2–6, 6–3 *It was Costa's 1st title of the year and the 9th of his career.
===Women's Singles=== {{main|1999 Estoril Open – Women's Singles}} {{flagicon|SLO}} '''[[Katarina Srebotnik]]''' defeated {{flagicon|HUN}} [[Rita Kuti-Kis]], 6–3, 6–1 *It was Srebotnik's 1st title of the year and the 2nd of her career.
===Men's Doubles=== {{main|1999 Estoril Open – Men's Doubles}} {{flagicon|ESP}} '''[[Tomás Carbonell]]''' / {{flagicon|USA}} '''[[Donald Johnson]]''' defeated {{flagicon|CZE}} [[Jiří Novák]] / {{flagicon|CZE}} [[David Rikl]], 6–3, 2–6, 6–1
===Women's Doubles=== {{main|1999 Estoril Open – Women's Doubles}} {{flagicon|ESP}} '''[[Alicia Ortuño]]''' / {{flagicon|ESP}} '''[[Cristina Torrens Valero]]''' defeated {{flagicon|HUN}} [[Anna Földényi]] / {{flagicon|HUN}} [[Rita Kuti-Kis]], 7–6<sup>(7–4)</sup>, 3–6, 6–3
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070430022723/http://www.estorilopen.net/1/en/home/default.asp Official Website] *[http://www.atpworldtour.com/Tennis/Tournaments/Estoril.aspx ATP Tournament Profile] *[http://www.sonyericssonwtatour.com/page/Tournaments/Info/0,,12781~292,00.html WTA Tournament Profile]

page.title: 2007 ICC World Cricket League Division One

revision.text:
The '''2007 ICC World Cricket League Division One''' was a [[One Day International]] [[cricket]] tournament played from 29 January 2007 to 7 February 2007 in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]]. Division One, which is the successor to the now defunct [[ICC 6 Nations Challenge]], is the highest tier of the [[World Cricket League]], and is effectively the second level of cricket below the 10 Test-playing nations. This tournament served as an important warm-up for the [[2007 Cricket World Cup]] that took place in the West Indies in March 2007.
Games were played at [[Nairobi Gymkhana Club]], Ruaraka Sports Club and Jaffery Sports Club, all located in Nairobi.
==Points table== {| class="wikitable" ! Place !! Team !! Played !! Won !! Lost !! Points !! [[Scotland national cricket team|Scotland]] and [[Kenya national cricket team|Kenya]] qualified for the [[2007 ICC World Cricket League Division One#Final|final]] which was won by Kenya. Both qualified for the [[2007 Twenty20 Cricket World Championship]] to be held in South Africa in September.<ref name="Preview of Series">[http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/worldcricketleague/content/story/278133.html A long way from home] "... place among the big boys in the inaugural Twenty20 World Championship in South Africa this September ..." from Cricinfo, retrieved 9 April 2007</ref>

{{Infobox football club | clubname = AS Pikine | image = AS Pikine (logo).png | fullname = Association Sportive de Pikine | nickname = | founded = 1970 | ground = [[Stade Al Djigo|Stade Alassane Djigo]], [[Pikine]] | capacity = 5,000 | chrtitle = President | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Senegal Premier League]] | season = 2014-15 | position = 13th, relegated | current = | website = | pattern_la1= | pattern_b1= | pattern_ra1= | pattern_sh1= | pattern_so1 | leftarm1= FF0000| body1=008000| rightarm1=FF0000| shorts1=FF0000| socks1=FF0000 | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = | pattern_ra2 = | pattern_sh2 = | pattern_so2 = | leftarm2=FF0000| body2=FFFFFF| rightarm2=FF0000| shorts2=FFFFFF| socks2=FFFFFF }}
'''Association Sportive de Pikine''' or simply '''AS Pikine''' is a Senegalese football club based in [[Pikine]]. They play at [[Stade Al Djigo|Stade Alassane Djigo]], which has a capacity of 5,000.
==History== The earlier club was established in 1921 and was called Niayes-Pikine.
The modern club was established in 1970, first known as '''ASC Niayes-Pikine''' up to the 2000s. AS Pikine entered Ligue 1 in 2009. They would win their first national championship and cup title at the same time for the 2013/14 season<ref>{{cite web|url=http://senepeople.com/2014/06/22/as-pikine-championne-du-senegal-2014/|title=AS Pikine est championne du Sénégal 2014 (''AS Pikine - Senegalese Champion of 2014'')|publisher=senepeople.com|accessdate=3 April 2015}}</ref> and headed to participate in the [[2015 CAF Champions League|CAF Champions league in 2015]] and challenged [[Étoile Filante de Ouagadougou]], a club from Burkina Faso and later into the first round where they lost to [[USM Alger|USM Algiers]] from Algeria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dzfoot.com/2015/04/03/caf-cl-116e-r-as-pikine-1-1-usm-alger-2-65946.php|title=CAF CL 1/16e R. : AS Pikine 1-1 USM Alger|publisher=dzfoot.com|date=3 April 2015|accessdate=9 July 2016}}</ref>
In the 2014-15 season, Pikine did not had a successful season, their continued appearance in Ligue 1 vanished after being inside the relegation zone and placed 13th after [[ASC Port Autonome]] with 28 points, 4 wins and a staggering 14 losses.<ref>[http://rsssf.com/tabless/sene2015.html 2014/15 Senegalese Ligue 1 at RSSSF] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905113512/http://rsssf.com/tabless/sene2015.html |date=September 5, 2015 }}</ref>
Pikine first appeared in the 2009 edition, the club came in 2011 and won their only League Cup title after defeating [[ASC Yakaar|Yakaar]] 2-1. Their second attempt for their second title vanished after the club lost to [[ASC Niarry Tally|Niarry Tally]] 1-0 in the 2012 league cup season.
==Achievements== *'''[[Senegal Premier League]]: 1''' :: 2014.
*'''[[Senegal FA Cup]]: 1''' :: 2014.
*'''[[Senegalese League Cup|Coupe de la Ligue]]: 1''' :: 2011.
*'''[[Senegal Second League|Senegal Second League (Ligue 2)]]: 1''' :: 2009

{{infobox country at games | NOC = AFG | NOCname = [[Afghanistan National Olympic Committee]] | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1996 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = | location = [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]] | competitors = 2 | sports = 1 | flagbearer = Mohammad Aman | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = 1936 | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Afghanistan]]''' competed at the '''[[1996 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]]. The Central Asian nation returned to the Olympic Games after missing the [[1992 Summer Olympics]] held in [[Barcelona]]. Afghanistan only sent three representatives to the Atlanta Games but light-middleweight boxer [[Mohammad Jawid Aman]] was disqualified after arriving at the Games too late for the [[weigh-in]]. The other participant, marathon runner [[Abdul Baser Wasiqi]] injured his [[hamstring]] prior to the race. He nevertheless took part in the marathon but finished last, more than two hours after the winner.[http://www.rediff.com/sports/2000/aug/17tal.htm "Taleban hope to get ban revoked"], Reuters, August 17, 2000 ==Athletics== {{details|Athletics at the 1996 Summer Olympics}} {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan="2"|Final |-style="font-size:95%" !Result !Rank |-align=center |align=left|[[Abdul Baser Wasiqi]] |align=left|[[Athletics at the 1996 Summer Olympics – Men's marathon|Marathon]] |4:24:17 |111 |} ==See also== * [[Afghanistan at the 1996 Summer Paralympics]] ==References== {{reflist}}

{{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Central Park | image = Central Park stand - geograph-477764.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Main Stand and Alex Menzies Stand | pushpin_map = Scotland Fife | pushpin_mapsize = 250 | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Fife | pushpin_label_position = left |coordinates = {{coord|56|06|31.46|N|3|20|49.55|W|type:landmark|display=inline}} | location = [[Cowdenbeath]], [[Fife]]
KY4 9QQ | opened = 1917 | renovated = 1995 (Alex Menzies Stand) | owner = [[Cowdenbeath F.C.]] | surface = [[Lawn|Grass]] | tenants = Cowdenbeath F.C. | seating_capacity = {{SPFL-stadiums|cowdenbeath}}}} '''Central Park''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Cowdenbeath]], [[Fife]], Scotland, used for [[Association football|football]] and [[stock car racing]]. It is situated in the centre of the town, just off the High Street, and has a capacity of {{SPFL-stadiums|cowdenbeath}}.{{cite web |url=http://spfl.co.uk/clubs/cowdenbeath/ |title=Cowdenbeath Football Club|publisher=Scottish Professional Football League |accessdate=11 November 2013}} The pitch size is 107 x 66 yards. Central Park has been the home ground of [[Scottish Professional Football League]] team [[Cowdenbeath F.C.]] since it opened in 1917. Stock car racing has taken place at the ground since 1970, and takes place on a tarmac racetrack surrounding the football pitch. Central Park was also previously a venue for [[greyhound racing]] between 1928 and 1965. ==History== Cowdenbeath F.C. played at Jubilee Park until 1888, and then at [[North End Park]]. The club moved to Central Park when it was opened in 1917.{{harvnb|Inglis|1996|p=437}} A main stand was built in 1921. A record crowd of 25,586 attended a [[Scottish League Cup]] tie against [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] in 1949.{{cite news|url=http://www.footballgroundguide.com/scotland/cowdenbeath.html|title=Cowdenbeath|accessdate=11 June 2013|publisher=Duncan Adams|work=Scottish Ground Guide}} Floodlights were first used in 1968, in a match against [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]]. Central Park was also used for [[greyhound racing]] and [[Motorcycle speedway|speedway]]. It became a [[stock car racing]] track in 1970, and has since hosted several world championships. Half of the main stand was destroyed by a fire in 1992. The surviving section of this stand is called the West Stand, or the Old Stand. Beside this the ' [[Alex Menzies]] Stand' (or New Stand) was opened in March 1995, giving a total seated capacity of 1,622. Along with this the club built new dressing rooms, a board room, function suite, and office facilities. Both stands have a row of floodlight pylons in front of them, which can obstruct supporters views. Three sides of the ground are uncovered terraces. ==Greyhound racing== Greyhound racing around Central Park started on 7 July 1928. A 400-yard circumference track had an inside hare and both handicap and level start racing took place. It was an all grass track and distances raced were 289 and 489 yards. Greyhound racing ceased in 1965.{{cite book|last=Barnes|first=Julia|title=Daily Mirror Greyhound Fact File|page =413|year=1988|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=0-948955-15-5}} ==Future== In 2011, there were plans for Cowdenbeath to move to a new stadium, to be located on the outskirts of Cowdenbeath.{{cite web |author=Social networks... Facebook Twitter |url=http://www.centralfifetimes.com/articles/1/23822 |title=News |publisher=Central Fife Times |date= |accessdate=2013-07-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625225539/http://www.centralfifetimes.com/articles/1/23822 |archivedate=25 June 2012 |df=dmy-all }}[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/13024840.stm Cowdenbeath take step towards new stadium], [[BBC Sport]], 11 April 2011 ==Transport== [[Cowdenbeath railway station]] is five minutes' walk from Central Park. The [[M90 motorway]] passes near Cowdenbeath, with Central Park reached by leaving the motorway at junction 3, taking the [[A92 road|A92]] for [[Kirkcaldy]]. The A909 road then leads into Cowdenbeath and free car parking is provided at the ground. ==References== {{reflist}} ; Sources *{{cite book| ref = harv | first = Simon | last = Inglis | title = Football Grounds of Britain | year = 1996 | publisher = Collins Willow | isbn = 0-00-218426-5 }} {{Cowdenbeath F.C.}} {{Football venues in Scotland}} {{Scottish greyhound tracks}} [[Category:Cowdenbeath F.C.]] [[Category:Football venues in Scotland]] [[Category:Motorsport venues in Scotland]] [[Category:Sports venues in Fife]] [[Category:Stock car racing venues]] [[Category:Defunct greyhound racing venues in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Scottish Football League venues]] [[Category:Scottish Professional Football League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1917]] [[Category:Greyhound racing in Scotland]]

{{Unreferenced|date=March 2009}} [[Image:Club Andino Bariloche Stevage.jpg|thumb|300px|The club's headquarters in Bariloche.]] '''Club Andino Bariloche''' is a mountaineering organisation based in [[San Carlos de Bariloche]], in the Argentinian Andes. It was founded on the 13th of August 1931 by [[Otto Meiling]], Emilio Frey, [[Juan Javier Neumeyer]] and [[Reinaldo Knapp]], a group of friends who were exploring the region and making first ascents. [[Emilio Frey]] became its first president and continued in this role during 30 years.
The club was responsible for the construction and running of a number of [[mountain hut]]s in the area. Throughout its history, it has organised and funded a large number of expeditions, including many ambitious first ascents throughout the Andes.
==Huts== Huts run by the club are as follows: *Refugio Emilio Frey. *Refugio Reynaldo Knapp. *Refugio Cerro López. *Vivac Velco. *Refugio San Martín (o Jakob). *Refugio Tronador Viejo. *Laguna Ilón - Vivac Papa Manuel *Refugio Manfredo Segre. (Laguna Negra) *Refugio Berghof. ([[Cerro Otto]]) *Refugio Otto Meiling. ([[Mount Tronador]]) *Refugio Neumeyer.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081006151744/http://clubandino.org/INSTITUCIONAL/quienes_somos.asp Club website]
[[Category:Climbing organisations]] [[Category:Sport in Río Negro Province]] [[Category:Bariloche]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Dreamstyle Stadium | nickname = Turner & Margaret Branch Fieldhttp://www.golobos.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/073112aab.html | image = Branch Field at University Stadium.png | image_size = 275px | caption = View of Stadium from south stands | location = 1111 University Boulevard SE, [[Albuquerque, New Mexico|Albuquerque, NM]] 87131 | coordinates = {{coord|35|4|1|N|106|37|42|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = 1958 | opened = September 17, 1960 | owner = University of New Mexico | operator = University of New Mexico | surface = [[FieldTurf]] | construction_cost = $4.1 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|4100000|1960}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = W.C. Kruger and Associates | former_names = University Stadium (1960–2017) | record_attendance = 44,760 (New Mexico vs. New Mexico State, 2005) | tenants = [[New Mexico Lobos football]] ([[NCAA]]) (1960–present)
[[New Mexico Bowl]] (NCAA) (2006–present) | seating_capacity = 30,000 (1960–1977)

39,224 (2010–present)http://www.golobos.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=26000&ATCLID=209096621 }} '''Dreamstyle Stadium''', formerly known as '''University Stadium''', is an outdoor [[American football|football]] [[stadium]] located on the south campus of the [[University of New Mexico]] in [[Albuquerque]].[http://www.kob.com/article/stories/S2711239.shtml Branch family purchase of naming rights] It is the home field of [[New Mexico Lobos]] [[New Mexico Lobos football|football]], which competes as a member of the [[Mountain West Conference]]. The stadium opened in September 1960 and currently has a [[seating capacity]] of 39,224. The playing surface, named '''Turner & Margaret Branch Field''', is oriented in the north-south configuration that is traditional for football venues. The stadium sits nearly a mile above sea level, at an elevation of 5,100 feet (1554 m).[http://msrmaps.com/image.aspx?T=2&S=12&Z=13&X=439&Y=4851&W=3&qs=%7cAlbuquerque%7cNM%7c Topographic map] from [[USGS]] ''[[The National Map]]'' ==History== ===Replacement of Zimmerman Field=== Before 1960, Lobos football teams played home games at [[Zimmerman Field]], a 16,000-seat stadium which was located just south of the current Zimmerman Library on the university’s main campus. The growth of the university after World War II, with the concomitant growth in the popularity of varsity athletics, made it clear by the mid-1950s that a new, larger football venue was needed. Increasing enrollments also meant that space on the main campus was at a premium. As such, it was decided that a new stadium would be constructed off of the main campus, which would both allow adequate space for a much larger stadium, and free up space for desperately needed academic facilities on the main campus. The university purchased land for the new stadium south of campus near the corner of Avenida Cesar Chavez and University Boulevard. This land became known as "south campus," and would eventually become the home of the entire UNM Athletic Department. Today, facilities located on south campus include [[The Pit (arena)|The Pit]] (now formally named Dreamstyle Arena), [[Isotopes Park]], the Lobo Tennis Club, Lobo Field, Lobo Softball field, the Rudy Davalos Basketball Center, athletics administration buildings, as well as the football stadium.http://www.unm.edu/campusmap.html[http://msrmaps.com/image.aspx?T=4&S=10&Z=13&X=1757&Y=19407&W=3&qs=%7cAlbuquerque%7cNM%7c Aerial photo] from [[USGS]] ''[[The National Map]]'' The new stadium was christened as University Stadium upon its opening in 1960. It consisted of grandstands along the east and west sidelines and a press box above the west stands. The stadium was built in an [[Arroyo (creek)|arroyo]], with the seating bowl created by the piling of excavated fill material to form earthen embankments on which the stands could be built. This "berm" style of construction placed the field below ground level with seats extending both above and below the natural grade. The initial construction cost of the stadium was just over $4 million. The inaugural football game at University Stadium took place on September 17, 1960, with the Lobos defeating an overmatched [[National University of Mexico]] team by a score of 77-6. A new press box with private suites was built before the 1976 season at a cost of $1.8 million. Because the stadium had been built on earthen fill, the press box had to be supported on large concrete piers that went down to the pre-existing ground level. In [[1995 in sports|1995]], UNM made a major addition to University Stadium with the construction of the L.F. "Tow" Diehm Athletic Facility, a field house and athletic training facility located just beyond the south end zone. The athletics department announced in late 2011 that grass playing field would be replaced with a synthetic playing surface. [[FieldTurf]] was chosen as the artificial turf system by the UNM athletic department, and it was in place for the 2012 football season.[http://www.abqjournal.com/sports/2012/05/13/unm-new-turf-for-12-not-later.html New playing turf, replaces grass] Through the end of the 2017 season, Lobos Football has an all-time record of 163-168-3 at Dreamstyle Stadium. === Naming rights === In 2012, naming rights for the stadium's playing surface were secured by local attorneys Turner and Margaret Branch, who are alumni and long-time donors to the UNM athletic department.http://www.bizjournals.com/albuquerque/blog/morning-edition/2012/08/university-stadium-football-turf-now.html Their $1.5 million donation to the “Lobo Leap to Excellence” capital campaign remains the second-largest single gift ever given to the athletic department by a living donor. On May 3, 2017, UNM announced a $10 million, 10-year naming-rights agreement with Dreamstyle Remodeling, a local Albuquerque construction company, covering both the University Stadium and University Arena. The venues were rechristened as Dreamstyle Stadium and [[The Pit (arena)|Dreamstyle Arena]].Jessica Dyer, [https://www.abqjournal.com/997706/dreamstyle-pledging-10-million-to-unm-most-goes-to-pit-stadium-naming-rights.html Dream deal for UNM nets $10 million over 10 years], Albuquerque Journal, May 3, 2017 ==Expansion== [[Image:UNM Stadium.jpg|thumb|The west stands and press box]] The stadium was expanded in 2001, with stands, new bathroom and concessions facilities constructed beyond the north end zone. UNM also added a large, state-of-the-art scoreboard that included the "LoboVision" video screen. In 2004, portable bleachers were donated to UNM by the city of [[Albuquerque, New Mexico|Albuquerque]] in 2004 to take the stadium's capacity beyond 39,000. Plans for future expansion have been adopted. The next phase of expansion includes renovations of the stadium's southwest and southeast corners, as well as adding 5,000 seats to the south end of the stadium. Additionally, a tunnel connecting Dreamstyle Stadium and the Tow Diehm Facility has also been planned to allow easier player access to locker rooms during games. When the currently planned renovations are completed, the stadium will seat over 43,000 spectators. ==Notable events== ===New Mexico Bowl=== {{Main|New Mexico Bowl}} Since December [[2006 NCAA Division I FBS football season|2006]], University Stadium has hosted the [[New Mexico Bowl]]. The game was funded by a $2 million line of credit from [[ESPN]], and the inaugural edition featured New Mexico against [[2010–13 Mountain West Conference realignment|future]] [[Mountain West Conference]] foe [[San Jose State Spartans football|San Jose State]], then of the [[Western Athletic Conference]]. SJSU defeated UNM 20-12. The game was the first Division I bowl game played in the state of New Mexico. University Stadium had hosted the Division II national championship, named the [[Zia Bowl]], in early December [[1979 in sports|1979]] and [[1980 in sports|1980]].http://cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/bowls/bowl_results.php?bowlid=327 In Zia Bowl I, [[Delaware Fightin' Blue Hens football|Delaware]] defeated [[Youngstown State Penguins football|Youngstown State]] 38-21. In Zia Bowl II, [[Cal Poly Mustangs football|Cal Poly-San Luis Obispo]] (now simply [[California Polytechnic State University|Cal Poly]]) beat [[Eastern Illinois Panthers football|Eastern Illinois]] 21-13. Attendance was 4,000 or less for both Zia Bowls, and in 1981 the Division II championship was moved to McAllen, Texas.http://www.d2championship.com/History/DII%20Champ%20History.pdf ===Soccer=== University Stadium hosted a [[U.S. women's national soccer team]] [[FIFA Women's World Cup|Women's World Cup]] qualifying match against [[Mexico women's national football team|Mexico]] in May [[2004 in sports|2004]]. Three [[United States men's national soccer team|U.S. men's national soccer team]] matches have been played in the stadium, with the most recent being a friendly match with [[Honduras national football team|Honduras]] in March [[2005 in sports|2005]]. ===Concerts=== The stadium has hosted concerts by many famous artists, including [[Metallica]] & [[The Rolling Stones]], among others. {| class="wikitable" style=font-size:100% style="text-align:center" |- ! width=12% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|New Mexico Lobos|color=white}};|Date ! width=10% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|New Mexico Lobos|color=white}};|Artist ! width=10% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|New Mexico Lobos|color=white}};|Opening act(s) ! width=16% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|New Mexico Lobos|color=white}};|Tour / Concert name ! width=10% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|New Mexico Lobos|color=white}};|Attendance ! width=10% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|New Mexico Lobos|color=white}};|Revenue ! width=20% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|New Mexico Lobos|color=white}};|Notes |- | August 2, 1994 || [[Metallica]] || [[Danzig (band)|Danzig]]
[[Suicidal Tendencies]]

{{One source|date=October 2012}} '''"Dynamic Tension"''' is the name [[Charles Atlas]] gave to the system of [[physical exercise]]s that he first popularized in the 1920s.
Dynamic Tension is a self-resistance exercise method which pits [[muscle]] against muscle. The practitioner tenses the muscles of a given body part and then moves the body part against the tension as if a heavy weight were being lifted. Dynamic Tension exercises are not merely [[isometric exercise|isometrics]], since they call for movement. Instead, the method comprises a combination of exercises in three disciplines: [[isotonic (exercise physiology)|isotonic]], [[isokinetic]], and some exercises in the isometric discipline.
Proponents assert that it is nearly impossible to be injured during exercise using this method because one's own muscles provide the force and, as they tire, so the force used also decreases. Likewise, the benefits can continue beyond the more traditional exercise methods because as the practitioner grows stronger, the exercise becomes more intense.
"Dynamic Tension" is a registered trademark of Charles Atlas, Ltd.
==History==
After being bullied as a child, Charles Atlas joined the [[YMCA]] and began to do numerous exercise routines. He became obsessed with strength. He said that one day he watched a [[tiger]] stretching in the [[zoo]] and asked himself, "How does Mr. Tiger keep in physical condition? Did you ever see a tiger with a [[barbell]]?" He concluded that [[lion]]s and tigers became strong by pitting muscle against muscle.
The story may be apocryphal, but it captures the essence of Mr. Atlas' innovation. There were many other "isometric" courses available at the time, and it only when Atlas used an advertisement depicting a bully kicking sand in the weakling's face that the sales took off.<ref>The 20th Century History With The Boring parts Left Out, D. Wallechinsky, 1999</ref> Some other notable users of this method include [[Joe DiMaggio]], [[Max Baer (boxer)|Max Baer]], [[Rocky Marciano]], [[Joe Louis]], [[Robert Ripley]] and [[Alan Wells]].
Specifically, dynamic tension is a technique very commonly used within martial arts. It refers to the "dynamic tension" literally applied using a person’s movements. Tightening core muscles and applying dynamic tension allows a person to change the tempo of his or her movement. The reconstruction of such movements gives a person more power and speed. That especially becomes useful in performing or sparring. Taking a deep breath, exhaling slowly while tightening the muscles, and sometimes even physically shaking the body part all portray a stronger presence while one performs. Following dynamic tension could be a series of quick movements to pick up the pace.
Dynamic tension is a technique that is universal and can be used on any movement or any style.

{{Infobox venue | name = Estadio Miguel Grau | fullname = | image = [[File:ESTADIO MIGUEL GRAU CALLAO.jpg|250px]] | image_size = | caption = | address = | location = [[Bellavista District|Bellavista]], [[Callao]], [[Peru]] | coordinates = {{Coord|-12.05972|-77.11995|type:landmark}} | type = Association football stadium | broke_ground = | built = | opened = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|1996|5|16}} | owner = [[Callao|Regional Government of Callao]] | surface = grass | cost = | capacity = 17,000 | record_attendance = 17,785 | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Sport Boys]]
[[Club Deportivo Universidad de San Martín de Porres|Universidad de San Martín]]
[[Academia Cantolao]] }} '''Estadio Miguel Grau''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in the [[Bellavista District]] of [[Callao]], [[Peru]]. The stadium is part of the Sport Village of Callao (''Villa Deportiva del Callao'') or ''Yahuar Huaca'', which is owned by the [[Callao#Government|Callao Regional Government]] since 2011.{{cite web|title=EL IPD criticó a Región Callao por violenta toma de complejo deportivo {{!}} El Comercio Peru|url=http://archivo.elcomercio.pe/sociedad/lima/ipd-critico-region-callao-violenta-toma-complejo-deportivo-violencia-noticia-694852|website=archivo.elcomercio.pe|accessdate=24 December 2017|language=es}} Its use is available to several [[football (soccer)|football]] teams in the region including [[Sport Boys]], [[Club Deportivo Universidad de San Martín de Porres|Universidad de San Martín]] and [[Academia Cantolao]] who play their home matches here for the [[Torneo Descentralizado]]. The stadium's maximum capacity is 17,000 and was inaugurated on 16 June 1996 with a match between [[Sport Boys]] and [[Deportivo Wanka|Deportivo Pesquero]] for the [[1996 Torneo Descentralizado]]. The match was a 3–1 win for Sport Boys.{{cite web|url=http://dechalaca.com/informes/opinion/la-casa-de-carton|title=La casa de cartón|last=Ortiz Jaime|first=Bruno|date=21 January 2011|language=Spanish|accessdate=22 January 2011}} Floodlight towers were installed in 2003. == References == {{reflist}} {{Torneo Descentralizado stadiums}} ==External links== *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/south_america/countries/peru.shtml] {{coord|-12.05972|-77.11995|display=t|type:landmark}} [[Category:Football venues in Peru|Miguel Grau]] [[Category:Sport Boys]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Callao Region]] {{Peru-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} The '''Football Trust''' was a Government funded body to improve the safety of sports stadiums in the United Kingdom.
It was set up by the Labour Government in 1975, with the assistance of the pools companies and the [[Football League]]. Its original primary purpose (when it was known as the Football Grounds Improvement Trust) was to assist with the costs of implementing the Safety of Sports Grounds Act 1975.
In October 1990, Chancellor of the Exchequer [[John Major]] reduced tax on the pools competitions such as "spot the ball" to help fund the trust.<ref>{{cite web|title=Football Stadia After Taylor: Centre for the Sociology of Sport, Department of Sociology|url=http://www.le.ac.uk/sociology/css/resources/factsheets/fs2.html|publisher=University of Leicester}}</ref>
It was chaired by [[Tom Pendry]].
{| class="wikitable" | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Club''' | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Grant (£)''' |- | Aston Villa | 3,476,361 |- | Blackburn Rovers||3,453,437 |- | Chelsea||4,402,949 |- | Coventry City||3,465,131 |- | Derby County||4,641,487 |- | Everton||2,465,325 |- | Leeds Utd||2,583,373 |- | Leicester City||2,712,447 |- | Liverpool||3,362,691 |- | Man Utd||3,692,619 |- | Middlesbrough||4,210,311 |- | Newcastle||3,418,275 |- | Sheffield Wednesday||4,299,086 |- | Sunderland||4,454,354 |- | Arsenal||3,072,167 |- | Bristol City||2,328,531 |- | Nottingham Forest||2,267,384 |- | [[Tottenham Hotspur]]||3,519,216 |- | West Ham||4,068,663 |- | [[Wembley F.C.|Wembley]]||2,057,253 |}
<ref>[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199899/cmselect/cmcumeds/124/124ap40.htm parliament.uk]</ref>
The Trust was wound up in 2000 and replaced with the [[Football Foundation]].

{{Multiple issues| {{Notability|date=November 2017}} {{Advert|date=November 2017}} }} {{Infobox organization | name = International Sports Promotion Society | native_name = 国際スポーツ振興協会 | image = File:ISPS Company Logo.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | abbreviation = ISPS, ISPS HANDA | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = {{start date|2006|||df=y}} | founder = [[Haruhisa Handa]] | extinction = | merger = | type = Non-profit | status = | purpose = To increase welfare through sports{{Cite web|url=http://www.scene.co.nz/foxes-foursome-and-new-naming-sponsor-for-open/325918a1.page |title=Foxes foursome and new naming sponsor for Open |publisher=Mountain Scene |location=[[Queenstown, New Zealand]] |date=November 12, 2015|accessdate=December 1, 2015}} | headquarters = [[Tokyo]], Japan | location = | coords = | region = | services = | membership = | language = | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | staff = | volunteers = | slogan = | website = {{url|www.ispsgolf.com/}} }} {{nihongo|'''International Sports Promotion Society'''|国際スポーツ振興協会|''Kokusai Spōtsu Shinkō Kyoukai''}} ('''ISPS''', also known as '''ISPS Handa''') is a Japanese non-profit organization known for sponsorship of the [[PGA Seniors Championship]] and [[Women's Australian Open|LPGA Women's Australian Open]] tournaments and promotion of dedicated to promoting the involvement of the visually disabled in golfing. ISPS Handa supports [[Disability classification in golf|blind golf]] worldwide. ISPS Handa is a member of the Tokyo Sports Association, a public interest incorporated foundation.{{Cite web |date=2013-03-01 |url=http://www.sporttokyo.metro.tokyo.jp/sports-sai-tokyo2013/kyogi/kokutai/pdf/guidance_14.pdf|title=公益財団法人東京都体育協会加盟競技団体等一覧表|publisher=[[Tokyo]]|language= Japanese|accessdate=2015-11-26}} The founder Haruhisa Handa is known for promoting [[Disability classification in golf|Blind Golf]] and introducing blind golf to Japan.{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/29/oly-para-golf-tournament-idUSL4E8G749Y20120629|title=Olympics-Father of blind golf pushing for Paralympic place|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=2012-06-29|accessdate=2014-06-14}} ISPS is committed to promote disabled golf to be adopted as an official event of the Paralympics.{{Cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/barrettwissman/2015/12/09/haruhisa-handa-in-tokyo-lost-and-found-in-translation/ |title=Haruhisa Handa in Tokyo: Lost and Found in Translation |author=Barrett Wissman |date=December 9, 2015 |publisher=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=December 28, 2015 }} == History == * ISPS Handa was founded in 2006, establishing “[[Handa Cup]]” in US, as well as the “Handa Australian Cup” in Australia to fund and support [[LPGA]] senior golf tournaments. It also began organizing amateur events such as the ''Handa Cup All-Japan Golf Tutors Pro-Am Open Championship.'' * Since 2007, ISPS Handa has also supported bowling tournaments in Japan, and has co-sanctioned Handa Cup Japan Pro Bowling Championship and Handa Cup All Japan Women's Pro Bowling Championship. It also began to establish and support tournaments for international major tours. * Since 2010, ISPS Handa has been hosting championships in Japan such as: JPGA Senior Tour and [[Japan Golf Tour|JGTO]] Challenge Tournament, including the ISPS Handa Cup Senior Masters. * In January 2012, ISPS Handa established the ISPS Handa PGA Academy Program, in which system UK professional golfers provide instruction to blind golfers, in collaboration with the [[PGA European Tour]].{{Cite news |date=July 20, 2014 |title=続・アカスリ半田劇場2 |trans-title=Zoku Akasuri Handa Theater 2 |language= Japanese |newspaper=Sports Nippon |location=Tokyo, Japan}} * In 2013, ISPS Handa organized [[World Sports Values Summit for Peace]] in Tokyo.{{cite news |date=July 19, 2013 |title=16カ国参加スポーツ平和サミット開幕 |trans-title=World Sports Values Summit for Peace Opens - Participants from 16 Nations |url=http://www.daily.co.jp/general/2013/07/19/0006172244.shtml |language=Japanese |newspaper=Daily Sports |location=Tokyo, Japan |accessdate=November 30, 2015}}{{cite web |date=July 19, 2013 |url=http://pga.or.jp/2013/07/post_1219.html#more |title=スポーツ平和サミット東京大会が開催-ｽﾎﾟｰﾂの力は無限大 |website=PGA News |publisher=Professional Golfers’Association of Japan |location=Tokyo, Japan |language=Japanese |script-title=公益社団法人　日本プロゴルフ協会 |trans-title=World Sports Values Summit for Peace in Tokyo is Held – The Power of Sports is Infinite |accessdate=November 30, 2015}} * In July 2014, ISPS Handa started supporting [[Mpumalanga Black Aces F.C.]] in the Republic of [[South Africa]].{{cite news |url=http://www.kickoff.com/news/47306/mpumalanga-black-aces-proud-of-isps-kit-deal- |title=Mpumalanga Black Aces proud of ISPS kit deal |newspaper=Kick Off |date=July 31, 2014 |accessdate=November 30, 2015}} * In June 2015, ISPS Handa founded [[ISPS Handa Global Cup]], its first hosting tournament in association with [[Japan Golf Tour|Japan Golf Tour Organization]].{{cite news |url=http://www.alba.co.jp/tour/news/article/no=36309 |title=ポールターにマスターズ覇者も! ISPSハンダグローバルカップ記者発表会開催 |trans-title=ISPS Handa Global Cup of the press conference held|newspaper=ALBA |location=Tokyo, Japan |language=Japanese |date=July 1, 2015 |accessdate=November 30, 2015}} == Golf == ISPS Handa promotes [[Disability classification in golf|disabled golf]] and blind golf,{{cite news |url=http://www.golf-monthly.co.uk/news/tour-news/isps-handa-let-sign-new-agreement-61839 |title=ISPS Handa and LET sign new agreement |newspaper=Golf Monthly |publisher=Time Inc. (UK) Ltd. |date=December 1, 2014 |accessdate=November 30, 2015}} and provides management and financial support to a number of tournaments in cooperation with the local golf associations worldwide. There have been a number of tournaments organized entitled “ISPS”, the abbreviation of International Sports Promotion Society and “HANDA” which is the last name of Haruhisa Handa, the Chairman, as well as the combined title “ISPS HANDA”. ISPS Handa became the title sponsor for the [[World Cup (men's golf)|2013 Golf World Cup]], resulting in the official title of the tournament as “ISPS Handa World Cup Golf”.{{Cite news |date=September 11, 2013 |title=ISPS HANDA becomes title sponsor of World Cup of Golf |publisher=[[PGA European Tour]] }}{{cite news |title=ISPSハンダがワールドカップのタイトルスポンサーに |trans-title=ISPS Handa becomes title sponsor of World Cup of Golf |newspaper=ParGolf |publisher=Pargolf & Company|date=September 11, 2013 |language= Japanese |location=Tokyo, Japan }}{{cite news |url=http://news.golfdigest.co.jp/news/article/46097/1/ |title=ISPSハンダがワールドカップのタイトルスポンサーに |trans-title=ISPS Handa becomes title sponsor of World Cup of Golf |newspaper=Golf Digest |date=September 11, 2013 |language= Japanese |location=Tokyo, Japan |accessdate=November 30, 2015}}{{cite news |url=http://news.golfdigest.co.jp/news/article/46097/1/ |title=ISPS HANDA becomes title sponsor of World Cup of Golf 2013 |newspaper=[[Sankei Sports]]|date=September 12, 2013 |language= Japanese |location=Tokyo, Japan}} The 6th PGA Handa Cup Philanthropy Senior Tournament (organized by The Professional Golfers’ Association of Japan), had total prize money 5 times higher than the previous year’s (2006 The 5th PGA Philanthropy Rebornest Senior Open), becoming the first “Total Prize Money 100,000,000 yen Tournament” in the history of the PGA Senior Tour. Since its 11th event in 2012, this Tournament has been organized by ISPS, and the 2014 event was entitled as the “ISPS Handa Cup Philanthropy Senior Tournament”. The ISPS Handa Global Cup ([[Japan Golf Tour Organization]]) launched in June, 2015, was broadcast overseas as a golf program with a commentator in English for the first time in the golf history of Japan. Besides the TV broadcast, the program was also distributed online through [[Ustream]]. The winner received as a prize a Japanese green [[Haori]], instead of the green jacket.{{Cite news |date=August 13, 2014 |title=続・アカスリ半田劇場3 |trans-title=Zoku Akasuri Handa Theater 3 |language= Japanese |newspaper=[[Sports Nippon]] |location=Tokyo, Japan}} === Current ISPS Handa Events === {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Cup Philanthropy in China CGA Challenge Tour || 2010 || China |- | JFOS || Handa Cup International || 2009 || China |} == Summit == ISPS co-sanctioned the [[World Sports Values Summit for Peace]] in [[Tokyo]], which was held on 18–19 July 2013. Top [[Athlete (sports)|athletes]] and [[researchers]] came together from 16 countries around the world to discuss the topic “Sports can contribute to harmonize the development of humanity and to establish and encourage a peaceful society”. At the World Sports Values Summit for Peace and Development, held on 23–24 May 2014 at the [[United Nations Headquarters]], [[New York City]], a partnership between ISPS and the United Nations [[Alliance of Civilizations]] (UNAOC) was announced.{{cite news|url=http://www.unaoc.org/2014/05/remarks-by-h-e-mr-nassir-abdulaziz-al-nasser-united-nations-high-representative-for-the-un-alliance-of-civilizations-at-the-world-sports-values-summit-for-peace-and-development/|title=Remarks by H.E. Mr. Nassir Abdulaziz Al-Nasser United Nations High Representative for the UN Alliance of Civilizations At The World Sports Values Summit for Peace and Development|newspaper=[[Alliance of Civilizations|UNAOC]] |publisher=[[Alliance of Civilizations|UNAOC]]|date=2014-05-22|accessdate=2014-10-19}} == Japan Bowling == In Japan ISPS supports bowling, hosting national tournaments throughout the year. In Japan roughly 20% of the population bowls, compared with the 13.8% who play golf. However, the number of bowling alleys has decreased from 3,000 to 1,000. Through the support of the ISPS, a number of bowling events have been held and the professionalism of the sport has been advanced. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! valign=top | Operated !! {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Jonava Sports Arena | image = [[File:Jonava Arena30.JPG|250px]] | nickname = | address = Žeimių g. 17, LT-55134 | location = [[Jonava]], [[Lithuania]] | coordinates = {{coord|55|4|35|N|24|16|23|E|display=inline,title|region:LT}} | broke_ground = 2010 | opened = 22 February 2017{{cite web|url=https://www.delfi.lt/sportas/kitos-sporto-sakos/pompastiskai-duris-atvere-nauja-jonavos-sporto-arena.d?id=73837260|title=Pompastiškai duris atvėrė nauja Jonavos sporto arena|website=DELFI Sportas|accessdate=2017-09-14}} | owner = [[Jonava District Municipality]] | construction_cost =9.4 million Euro | contractor = | architect = UAB „Projektų centras“ | tenants = [[BC Jonava]]
[[Achema-KKSC]] | seating_capacity = [[Concert]]s 2,800
[[Basketball]] 2,200 }} '''Jonava Sports Arena''' is an indoor arena in [[Jonava]], Lithuania. Mostly used for basketball and volleyball games. == History == Although construction works started in 2010 arena was not opened until early 2017 due lack of funding.{{cite web|url=http://www.jonavoszinios.lt/atidaryta-jonavos-sporto-arena|title=Atidaryta Jonavos sporto arena|website=Jonavos žinios|accessdate=2017-09-14}} In 2015 fire started and spread across the roof of unfinished arena which resulted in more delays. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.jonavosarena.lt Official website of Arena] {{DEFAULTSORT:Jonava arena}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Lithuania]] [[Category:Sports venues in Jonava]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Lithuania]] {{Lithuania-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Multiple issues| {{Primary sources|date=October 2016}} {{More citations needed|date=October 2016}}}} {{Infobox martial art group | logo =Kudo.jpg | logocaption = | logosize = | image = | imagecaption = | imagesize = | name = 空道 Kudo Daido Juku | aka = | date founded = 1981 | country = {{flagicon|Japan}} Japan | founder = | head = Azuma Takashi | arts = | ancestor_arts = [[Karate]], [[Judo]], [[Boxing]] | ancestor schools = | notable_pract = Azuma Takashi | website = http://ku-do.com }} {{nihongo|'''Kūdō'''|空道|Kūdō}} (formerly ''Kakutō karate'' (格闘空手); often ''Daidōjuku'') is a [[Japan]]ese [[hybrid martial art]]. It is full-contact mixed combat sport with head Guard and gloves, throwing and grappling techniques are also allowed in the competition, including restraint, locks and [[strangle hold]]s. It can be called a mixed martial art with protective gear for the head{{cite web|url=http://www.ku-do.com/|title=Kudo International Federation - KIF is a governing organization for "KUDO", mixed Budo sport|website=Ku-do.com|accessdate=2016-10-20}} The goal of Kūdō is to come as close as possible to realistic, real fighting, with appropriate protective clothing. To achieve this, Kūdō is fought with very few regulations, and has specialized techniques and actions. The techniques of Kūdō include the entire spectrum of a real struggle-fighting standing up, throwing techniques, grappling and ground fighting. The training of Kūdō consists primarily of [[kihon]], general fitness training and combat. The [[kata]] of Kyokushin were eliminated without replacement. Kūdō is a comprehensive martial art and philosophy, in which both the physical as well as mental development are considered. Traditional [[Japanese etiquette]] [[Budō|Budo]] (as [[Reigi]]) is followed, there are certain Japanese greeting ritual, a traditional training [[keikogi]] is worn, the names of the techniques are in Japanese, etc. [[File:KIF Affiliated Countries & Aspirants (2011-10-31).png|thumb|right|Member countries (red) and candidate member countries (green) of the Kudo International Federation (October 31, 2011)]] Kūdō is practiced in more than 52 countries, with the largest representation in Russia.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} == Takashi Azuma == [[File:Azuma Takashi.jpg|thumb|right]] {{nihongo|'''Takashi Azuma'''|東 孝|Azuma Takashi}} (born 1949 in [[Kesennuma]], Japan) is the founder of Kūdō{{cite web|url=https://deportes.terra.cl/luchas/panamericano-de-kudo-en-chile-sera-dirigido-por-su-fundador,cb40d74d8271f194cbd0dc969613a904wizl78o1.html|title=Panamericano de Kudo en Chile será dirigido por su fundador|publisher=[[Terra Chile]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com.co/elpais/juegos-mundiales/noticias/kudo-gran-camino-para-tener-mente-abierta|title=Kudo: El gran camino para tener una mente abierta|publisher=[[El País (Cali)|El País]]}} and the President of the Kudo International Federation. He currently holds an 8th degree [[black belt (martial arts)|black belt]] in [[Kyokushin]] Budokai (awarded by [[Jon Bluming]]), a 3rd degree black belt in judo, and a 9th degree black belt in Kūdō. Azuma came in contact with [[Budō|budo]] for the first time when he entered the [[judo]] club of his school in Kesennuma at the age of 16 in 1965. In 1972 after his service in the [[Japanese armed forces]], he joined [[Kyokushin Karate]]. That same year he founded a Kyokushin [[dan (rank)|dan]] at [[Waseda University]].{{cite web|url=http://www.daidojuku.com/eng/daidojuku/jukucho.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-10-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019232400/http://www.daidojuku.com/eng/daidojuku/jukucho.html |archivedate=2013-10-19 |df= }} In 1981, Azuma founded his own martial art because he was unhappy with some characteristics of Kyokushin. Azuma was bothered that in Kyokushin serious head injuries are common. Azuma was also of the opinion that physically smaller fighters are at a disadvantage compared to bigger fighters. Azuma's own development of a martial art was first a hybrid of Kyokushin Karate and Judo. Kyokushin was the basis, however, the regulations changed dramatically. Protective clothing was introduced, which allowed hand techniques to the head, and provides sufficient protection to the head during kicking techniques. Selected techniques of grappling and ground combat have been added from judo. Later, more martial arts and combat sports were analyzed and added to selected elements of its own martial art, primarily techniques of [[Muay Thai]] and [[jujutsu]]. == Famous practitioners == * [[Semmy Schilt]], [[mixed martial artist]] and [[kickboxer]]. Hokutoki champion in 1996 and 1997. * Yoshinori Nishi, mixed martial arts fighter and founder of the Wajyutsu Keishukai gym. Hokutoki champion in 1984 and 1985. * [[Lee Hasdell]], mixed martial artist and kickboxer. * [[Katsumasa Kuroki]], [[professional wrestler]]. * Minoki Ichihara, mixed martial artist and [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]] competitor. * [[Hisaki Kato]], Mixed Martial Artist who compete in Bellator MMA and Kickboxing. * [[Akshay Kumar]] Bollywood super star and martial artist. * [[Taapsee Pannu]] Bollywood actress and martial artist. ==Equipment== Kudo practitioners use white and blue Gi colors for easy identification along with independently developed protective gear (face, torso, arms, legs, etc.) to ensure athletes safety. All athletes must wear dogi, headgear, kudo fist guard and kudo bandage. Headgear own a special visior in plexiglass. ==Dojo kun== Dōjō kun is a Japanese martial arts term literally meaning (training hall) rules. They are generally posted at the entrance to a dōjō or at the "front" of the dojo (shomen) and outline behaviour expected and disallowed. The dojo kun of kudo is the following:
Through the pursuit of Kudo, we develop great physical and mental strength, educate ourselves and gain intelligence, and bond with people and enrich our emotions. Therefore, we shall be able to cultivate our personalities and become positively contributing members of society.
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.ku-do.com/ Kūdō International Federation official website] * [http://www.kudo-uk.com/ Kudo International website] * [http://www.daidojuku.com/ Daidojuku dōjō official website] * [http://Www.kudoindia.org/ Kudo International Federation India official website ] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Oj5qZshKsnY Youtube.com: Russian Team in Kūdō World Championship 2009] * [https://www.rt.com/sport/kudo-world-cup-moscow/ Russia knocks opponents out at home Kudo World Cup] [[Category:Japanese martial arts]] [[Category:Combat sports]] [[Category:Hybrid martial arts]]

{{Infobox stadium | name = Leangen Ishall | nickname = | image = Leangen Ishall.jpg | fullname = | former_names = | location = [[Trondheim]], [[Oslo]], [[Norway]] | coordinates = {{Coord|63|25|40|N|10|27|58|E|type:landmark_region:NO|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1977 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Trondheim]] Kommune | operator = | surface = [[Ice]] | scoreboard = | construction_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 3,000 | record_attendance = | dimensions = | tenants = [[Trondheim Black Panthers]] (–2008)
[[Rosenborg IHK]] (–2014)
[[Nidaros Hockey]] (2015–present) }} '''Leangen Ishall''' is an indoor [[Ice hockey rink|ice hockey arena]] located in [[Leangen]], [[Trondheim]], [[Norway]]. The capacity of the arena is 3,000 and it was opened in 1977.[http://www.hockey.no/t2.asp?p=61305 Norwegian ice hockey venues] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706024852/http://www.hockey.no/t2.asp?p=61305 |date=2011-07-06 }} at hockey.no It is the home arena of the [[Nidaros Hockey|Nidaros]] [[ice hockey]] team. The arena also hosted the home games of the [[Trondheim Black Panthers]] and [[Rosenborg IHK|Rosenborg]] ice hockey team. Located next to the arena is [[Leangen Kunstisbane]] an outdoor long track artificial speed skating oval constructed in 1979.{{cite web|title=Leangen Kunstisbane|url=http://www.speedskatingnews.info/?page_id=826&bahn=NOTR|publisher=Speed Skating News|accessdate=13 October 2011}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|1=http://www.trondheim.kommune.no/content.ap?thisId=1117636404}} {{Sport in Trondheim}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Norway]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Norway]] [[Category:Sports venues in Trondheim]] [[Category:Speed skating venues in Norway]] [[Category:Rosenborg IHK]] [[Category:Trondheim Black Panthers]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1977]] [[Category:1977 establishments in Norway]] {{Norway-sports-venue-stub}}

[[File:FIS Ski Weltcup Titisee-Neustadt 2016 - Stefan Kraft2.jpg|thumb|[[Stefan Kraft]] has held the official world record of {{convert|253.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} since 2017]] [[File:VikersundbakkenWorld Cup Ski flying 2011.jpg|thumb|''[[Vikersundbakken]]'' in [[Vikersund]], Norway, where the current world record stands]] [[Ski jumping]] is a [[winter sport]] in which athletes compete on distance and style in a jump from a [[ski jumping hill]]. The sport has traditionally focused on a combination of style and distance, and it was therefore early seen as unimportant in many milieus to have the longest jump.{{cite web|url=http://www.skimuseum.ca/bios/Nelsen_Nels.pdf |title=Nels Nelsen |author=[[Canadian Ski Hall of Fame]] |format=PDF |accessdate=15 February 2011 |archivedate=15 February 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wWWQUfHu?url=http://www.skimuseum.ca/bios/Nelsen_Nels.pdf |deadurl=yes |df= }} The [[International Ski Federation]] (Fédération Internationale de Ski; FIS) has largely been opposed to the inflation in hill sizes and setting of distance records, and no world records have been set at [[ski jumping at the Winter Olympics|Olympic]], [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships|World Championship]], [[Holmenkollen Ski Festival]] or [[Four Hills Tournament]] events, as these have never been among the largest hills in the world. Since 1936, when the first jump beyond {{convert|100|m|ft}} was made, all world records in the sport have been made in the discipline of [[ski flying]], an offshoot of ski jumping where distance is explicitly emphasised. As of March 2017, the official world record for the longest ski jump is {{convert|253.5|m|ft|abbr=on}}, set by [[Stefan Kraft]] at [[Vikersundbakken]] in [[Vikersund]], Norway. Two years prior, also in Vikersund, [[Dimitry Vassiliev]] reached {{convert|254|m|ft|abbr=on}} but fell upon landing; his jump is unofficially the longest ever made.{{cite web|url=https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/blogs/world-of-sport/ski-jump-world-record-broken-for-second-time-in-two-days-as-anders-fannemel-flies-to-glory-164459525.html|author=[[Eurosport]]|title=Ski jump world record broken for second time in two days as Anders Fannemel flies to glory|date=15 February 2015|accessdate=15 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150217025612/https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/blogs/world-of-sport/ski-jump-world-record-broken-for-second-time-in-two-days-as-anders-fannemel-flies-to-glory-164459525.html|archivedate=17 February 2015|df=}} ==History== Ski jumping originated in Norway, and has been practiced since time immemorial, using handmade temporary hills.{{harvnb|Thoresen|2007|p=18}} The first record is credited to [[Olaf Rye]], a soldier who set up a show spectated by his fellow soldiers in 1808, reaching {{convert|9.5|m|ft}} in [[Eidsberg]], Norway. This small hill was probably near [[Eidsberg church]], possibly at the farm Lekum.{{harvnb|Thoresen|2007|p=15}} [[Sondre Norheim]], credited as the 'father' of modern skiing,{{harvnb|Thoresen|2007|p=21}} made the second official record at {{convert|19.5|m|ft}} in 1868. Tim Ashburn says in his book ''The History of Ski Jumping'' that Norheim's longest jump on the circular track in Haugli ground in 1868 should have been measured at {{convert|31.5|m|ft}},({{ISBN|1-904057-15-2}}, p. 14) but that newspapers in [[Oslo|Christiania]] reported that the length "was a little exaggerated", so the official record is everywhere written as 19.5 m. The sport quickly spread to Finland, the United States and Canada, where some of the subsequent records were set.{{harvnb|Thoresen|2007|p=371}} Early jumping competitions were only scored by style, and it was seen as disruptive to attempt to jump further. Not until 1901 was a scoring system for distance introduced.{{harvnb|Thoresen|2007|p=26}} With the construction of ''[[Bloudkova Velikanka]]'' in [[Planica]], Yugoslavia, in 1934,{{harvnb|Thoresen|2007|p=70}} the separate discipline of [[ski flying]] was introduced, which is essentially an 'extreme' version of ski jumping. With one exception, all of the world records for distance have been set on five of the world's six ski flying hills, of which five remain in use.{{harvnb|Thoresen|2007|pp=371–373}} In 1936, [[Josef Bradl|Josef "Sepp" Bradl]] was the first to surpass the {{convert|100|m|ft}} mark, landing a jump of {{convert|101.5|m|ft}}.{{harvnb|Thoresen|2007|p=74}} The FIS was long opposed to ski flying as a whole, and it has never been included in the Olympic or Nordic World Ski Championships. However, since 1972, the [[FIS Ski Flying World Championships]] has been a mainstay event, and ski flying event are also part of the [[FIS Ski Jumping World Cup]] calendar. The first to officially reach {{convert|200|m|ft}} was [[Toni Nieminen]] in 1994, by landing a jump of {{convert|203|m|ft}}; at the time, ski jumpers did not receive distance points for the part of the jumps exceeding 191 metres.{{harvnb|Thoresen|2007|p=239}} The distance of a ski jump is measured from the end of the 'table' (the very tip of the 'inrun' ramp) to halfway between the athletes' feet when they touch ground. To qualify, the jump must be made in a sanctioned competition, or official trial or qualification runs for these, with a system to control the actual length. To win a competition, an athlete needs both distance and style, the latter of which is achieved by attaining a proper [[Telemark landing]]; therefore jumpers are not motivated to jump as far as possible, only as far necessary to attain a good landing. Jumps are invalid if the jumper falls, defined as touching the ground with his hands or body before reaching the fall line. However, if an athlete touches the snow with any part of their body after landing, and receives style points greater than 14 from at least three judges, the jump is valid and counts as an official world record.English commentary by David Goldstrom after [[Kamil Stoch]]'s first-round jump, from the [[Eurosport 1]] broadcast in [[Letalnica bratov Gorišek|Planica]] on 26 March 2017 When ski flying began in the 1930s, jumps were recorded in a traditional [[Scandinavia]]n measure of length, the [[alen (unit of length)|Danish alen]] (1 alen (Denmark) = {{convert|0.6277|m|ft|abbr=on}}). Some older United States and Canadian records were recorded in feet. Now, jump length is measured by the meter. Today, camera technology capably makes the measurements. Before, spectators were stationed downhill, meter by meter, and the raised hand of the nearest observer marked the jumper's landing.{{cite web |url=http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/11-distance-measuring |title=Distance measurement |author=[[International Ski Federation]] |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707224542/http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/11-distance-measuring |archivedate=7 July 2011 |df= }} ==Official world records== ===Men=== [[File:Rye Olaf.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Olaf Rye]], who made the first recorded ski jump of {{convert|9.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} in 1808]] {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left; line-height:16px; width:80%;" !style="background-color: #ccc;" width="20"|{{Abbr|No.|Number}} !style="background-color: #ccc;" width="120"|Date !style="background-color: #ccc;" width="180"|Athlete !style="background-color: #ccc;" width="140"|Country !style="background-color: #ccc;" width="230"|Hill !style="background-color: #ccc;" width="230"|Location !style="background-color: #ccc;" width="40"|Metres !style="background-color: #ccc;" width="40"|Yards !style="background-color: #ccc;" width="40"|Feet |- | align=center|1 | 22 November 1808 | [[Olaf Rye]] | {{flag|Norway}}

[[Tauplitz]]/[[Bad Mitterndorf]], [[Austria]] | align=center|200 | align=center|218.7 | align=center|656 |} ==Invalid world records== If an athlete touches the ground with their hands, body, or falls before reaching the outrun line, the jump is deemed invalid and thus not listed as a world record. Jumps landed during non-competition training rounds or hill tests are also not recognized as official world records. Distances set by test jumpers (''Vorspringer'', or "V-jumpers") during competition rounds are deemed official. === Winter === [[File:SFC Vikersund 2012 Dimitry Vassiliev The first ski jumping tests on plastic without any audience were made on 31 October 1954 at Regenbergschanze in [[Zella-Mehlis]], [[East Germany]]. The ''Wadeberg Jugendschanze'' K40 in [[Oberhof, Germany|Oberhof]], East Germany, which was built just next to the old Thüringenschanze, officially became the world's first plastic covered ski jumping hill. On 21 November 1954 they organized first ever and at the same time regional competition on plastic at »Wadeberg Jugendschanze K40« in front of 15,000 spectators where [[Werner Lesser]] set first two ever plastic/summer world records of 41 and 42 metres (135 & 138 ft). Russian ski jumper [[Dimitry Vassiliev]] holds the current summer world record on plastic with 147.5 metres (484 ft) which he set at [[Russia]]n National Championships on 15 October 2016 in [[Sochi]], [[Russia]]. revision.text:
{{Use Canadian English|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Raymond Chabot Grant Thornton Park | nickname = | image = [[File:RCGT Park.PNG|310px]]
[[File:jetformpark.jpg|300px]] | location = 300 Coventry Rd
Ottawa, ON K1K 4P5 | broke_ground = | opened = 17 April 1993 | closed = | demolished = | owner = City of Ottawa| operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = {{CAD|17 million}} | architect = | former_names = Ottawa Baseball Stadium (2008–2015)
Ottawa Rapidz Stadium (2008)
Lynx Stadium (2003–2007)
JetForm Park (1993–2002)| tenants = [[Ottawa Lynx]] ([[International League|IL]]) (1993–2007)
[[Ottawa Rapidz]] ([[Can-Am League]]) (2008)
[[Ottawa Fat Cats]] ([[Intercounty Baseball League|IBL]]) (2010–2012)
[[Ottawa Champions]] (Can-Am League) (2015-present) | seating_capacity = 10,332 | dimensions = Left Field – {{convert|325|ft|m|abbr=on}}
Centre Field – {{convert|404|ft|m|abbr=on}}
Right Field – {{convert|325|ft|m|abbr=on}}
Alleys – {{convert|380|ft|m|abbr=on}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} '''Raymond Chabot Grant Thornton Park''' (formerly '''JetForm Park''', '''Lynx Stadium''', and '''Ottawa Baseball Stadium'''), also known as '''RCGT Park''' is a [[baseball stadium]] in [[Ottawa]], Ontario, Canada with a seating capacity of 10,332.[http://web.minorleaguebaseball.com/ballpark/page.jsp?ymd=20050518&content_id=7018&vkey=ballpark_t501&fext=.jsp&sid=t501 Lynx Stadium Facts] The stadium is located in the city's east end near the interchange of [[Queensway (Ottawa)|Queensway]] and [[Riverside Drive (Ottawa)|Vanier Parkway]]. It has been used for minor-league professional baseball and music concerts since 1993. ==History== The stadium was built to house the [[Ottawa Lynx]] of the International League and opened prior to the 1993 season. In its first season, the Lynx sold out 43 games and set an International League attendance record by averaging 9,772 fans per game. However, annual attendance steadily declined from there, except for a modest increase in 2001. By 2006, Ottawa had the lowest average attendance in the league.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/ottawa/story/2006/08/25/lynx-fri.html | title=Baseball Lynx to stay in Ottawa, for now | date=25 August 2006 | accessdate=7 September 2009 | publisher=[[CBC News]] }} The Lynx relocated after the 2007 season. After the departure of the Lynx, the City of Ottawa considered other proposals for the site but kept the stadium as a baseball facility for the following season. Among the proposals rejected by the city in 2007 were: * conversion of the stadium into the "Steelback Centre", a variable-use complex that could host 25,000 for concerts and 15,000 for sporting events as proposed by [[Frank D'Angelo]] of [[Steelback Brewery]];{{cite news | url=http://www.ottawabusinessjournal.com/289740073760027.php | accessdate=3 September 2007 | date=3 September 2007 | title=Businessman reveals ambitious plans for Lynx Stadium | first=Roman | last=Zakaluzny |work=[[Ottawa Business Journal]] |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928061259/http://www.ottawabusinessjournal.com/289740073760027.php |archivedate = 28 September 2007}} * replacement of the stadium by a casino; * replacement of the stadium with a larger Ottawa Congress Centre; * redevelopment of the site as conventional retail or office space. A new team, the [[Ottawa Rapidz]] of the [[Canadian American Association of Professional Baseball|Can-Am League]], was established in December 2007 and began to play in 2008. Despite attracting higher attendance than the Lynx in its final season, the Rapidz declared bankruptcy on September 29, 2009.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/ottawa-rapidz-go-under-1.733370 | title=Ottawa Rapidz go under | date=30 September 2008 | publisher=[[CBC News]] | accessdate=7 September 2009 }} A new team, the Voyageurs, was announced by the Can-Am league for the 2009 season. However, the league was faced with a lack of prospective owners for the team and with declining economic conditions and disbanded the Voyageurs in March 2009.{{cite news | url=http://ottawa.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20090821/OTT_baseball_090821/20090821/?hub=OttawaHome | title=Owner making play for another Ottawa pro baseball team | date=21 August 2009 | publisher=[[CJOH-TV|CTV Ottawa]] | accessdate=7 September 2009 }} The stadium remained unused in 2009 except for a late-August series of community baseball games sponsored by Ottawa city councillor [[Bob Monette]].{{cite news|url=https://ottawacitizen.com/sports/Ottawa+stadium+idle+more/1942743/story.html |title=Ottawa stadium to be idle no more / Monette arranges for area teams to play games at field |first=Darren |last=Desaulniers |work=Ottawa Citizen |date=29 August 2009 |accessdate=7 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901011421/http://www.ottawacitizen.com/sports/Ottawa+stadium+idle+more/1942743/story.html |archivedate=1 September 2009 }} Earlier, following the demise of the Voyageurs, Monette had suggested that the stadium be dismantled and the land sold to generate funds which could be applied to a new sports venue.{{cite news | url=http://ottawa.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20090401/OTT_Stadium_090401?hub=OttawaHome | title=Councillors consider tearing down baseball stadium | publisher=[[CJOH-TV|CTV Ottawa]] | date=1 April 2009 | accessdate=7 September 2009 }} In August 2009, area businessmen Dave Butler and Duncan MacDonald presented a proposal which would renovate the existing stadium facility for activities throughout the year, including use as a venue for [[Winterlude]].{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/ottawa/story/2009/08/24/ottawa-baseball-stadium.html | title=New Ottawa baseball pitch lands at city | date=24 August 2009 | accessdate=7 September 2009 | publisher=[[CBC News]] }} In January 2010, the [[Intercounty Baseball League]] voted 6–2 in favour of presenting the Ottawa Stadium Group with an expansion franchise that would play at the Ottawa Baseball Stadium[http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100226/OTT_baseball_return_ottawa_100226/20100226/?hub=OttawaHome CTV Ottawa- Baseball returns to play in Ottawa Stadium] On March 10, 2010, the IBL confirmed that the application for an IBL expansion franchise had been accepted.{{cite press release |title=IBL CONFIRMS OTTAWA ENTRY FOR 2010 SEASON – 3/10/2010 |publisher=Intercounty Baseball League |date=10 March 2010 |url=http://www.theibl.ca/tml/content/NewsArticle.aspx?newsid=512&page=1&categoryid=0&year=2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706205439/http://www.theibl.ca/tml/content/NewsArticle.aspx?newsid=512&page=1&categoryid=0&year=2010 |archivedate=6 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The new team, the [[Ottawa Fat Cats]], played from 2010 through 2012.{{cite news | url=https://ottawacitizen.com/sports/local-sports/pro-baseball-returns-to-the-plate-in-ottawa | title= Pro baseball returns to the plate in Ottawa | newspaper=Ottawa Citizen | first=Ken | last=Warren | date=11 June 2014 | accessdate=13 March 2015}} After spending two years negotiating with various ownership groups to bring a double-A baseball franchise to Ottawa, including a prospective deal with [[Mandalay Sports Entertainment|Mandalay Baseball]] which required the city to invest $40 million in stadium renovations, the city signed a ten-year lease with the Can-Am League to field a team in 2015, named the [[Ottawa Champions]].{{cite news | last = Reevely | first = David | title = Ottawa’s Double-A baseball dream is dead | newspaper = Ottawa Citizen | location = Ottawa | publisher = Ottawa Citizen | date = 23 September 2013 | url = https://ottawacitizen.com/sports/Ottawa+Double+baseball+dream+dead/8954160/story.html | accessdate = 19 July 2014 }}{{cite news | last = Brownlee | first = Mark | title = Double-A baseball team off the table for Ottawa | newspaper = Ottawa Business Journal | location = Ottawa | publisher = Ottawa Business Journal | date = 25 September 2013 | url = http://www.obj.ca/Local/City-Hall/2013-09-25/article-3405837/Double-A-baseball-team-off-the-table-for-Ottawa/1 | accessdate = 19 July 2014 }}{{cite news | last = Warren | first = Ken | title = Pro baseball is back in Ottawa and they're already Champions | newspaper = Ottawa Citizen | location = Ottawa | publisher = Ottawa Citizen | date = 16 June 2014 | url = https://ottawacitizen.com/sports/baseball/pro-baseball-is-back-in-ottawa-and-theyre-already-champions | accessdate = 19 July 2014 }} ===Branding=== Ottawa company [[JetForm]] first bought the naming rights to the Stadium. The name was changed to simply "Lynx Stadium" after the 2002 season when JetForm changed its name to Accelio. Accelio was in turn bought by Adobe Systems. For the 2008 season, the Rapidz marketed the stadium as "Rapidz Stadium". On March 12, 2015, it was announced that accounting firm [[Raymond Chabot Grant Thornton]] had signed a multi-year naming rights deal, giving the park its current name.{{cite web | url=http://www.ottawachampions.com/en/ottawa-champions-baseball-club-and-raymond-chabot-grant-thornton-announce-naming-rights-for-ottawa-stadium/ | title=Ottawa Champions Baseball Club and Raymond Chabot Grant Thornton Announce Naming Rights for Ottawa Stadium | publisher=[[Ottawa Champions]] | date=12 March 2015 | accessdate=12 March 2015}} ==Design== The stadium is in the split-level design, with a concourse running around the middle of the seating bowl. This concourse is at street level, so fans in the "lower" seats walk down, and fans in the "upper" seats walk up. All seats are blue chair-back models. Concessions, restrooms, a gift shop, and a kids' play area are located along a wider concourse (also at street level) located underneath the upper seats. The stadium also features skyboxes and the "Upper Deck" restaurant (open to all fans) perched behind home plate. While the windows do open, there is no outdoor seating at this level. Access is by elevator from the concourse below. There are open-air picnic tables down the left-field line which are also available to all fans. Coventry Road runs along the left-field fence, and games can easily be seen from the street while driving or walking. There is less than {{convert|50|ft|m}} of buffer between the stadium wall and the road, so flying balls can occasionally pose a hazard to passing cars. ==Concerts== Concerts have been held at the stadium on rare occasions: * July 19, 1998: Stardust Picnic with [[Blue Rodeo]], [[Great Big Sea]], [[54-40]], [[The Waltons (Canadian band)|The Waltons]] and [[Weeping Tile (band)|Weeping Tile]]; * September 20-21, 2002: Molson Canadian Snowjam featuring [[Treble Charger]], [[Dropkick Murphys]], [[Goldfinger (band)|Goldfinger]], [[Gob (band)|Gob]], [[Swollen Members]], [[Simple Plan]], [[Mudmen]], and [[Bowling For Soup]];{{cite news | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/75160/molson-brings-summer-snow-music | title=Molson Brings Summer Snow, Music | date=9 July 2002 | work=Billboard | accessdate=13 March 2015 }} * July 5, 2007: [[Nickelback]], [[Daughtry (band)|Daughtry]], [[Puddle of Mudd]], [[State of Shock (band)|State of Shock]]{{cite news | url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/N/Nickelback/ConcertReviews/2007/07/06/4317819-sun.html | publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer|Canoe]] | first=Ann Marie | last=McQueen | date=6 July 2007 | title=Lynx Stadium, Ottawa – July 5, 2007 }} ==Gallery== {| |[[File:lynxstadium1.jpg|thumb|320px|View behind home plate]] |[[File:lynxstadium2.jpg|thumb|320px|View from south side]] |} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Portal|Ottawa}} *[http://www.ballparkreviews.com/ottawa/ottawa.htm Ballpark Reviews – Raymond Chabot Grant Thornton Park] *[http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2002/Ottawa/Ottawa.htm Raymond Chabot Grant Thornton Park Views – ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] {{Coord|45|25|12.51|N|75|39|12.85|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=title}} {{Can-Am League Stadiums}} {{Ottawa landmarks}} [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Ottawa]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Ontario]] [[Category:1993 establishments in Ontario]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1993]]

{{About|the style of amateur wrestling practiced at the high school level in the United States|amateur wrestling that is practised at the college and university level in the United States|Collegiate wrestling}} {{Infobox martial art | name = Scholastic Wrestling | aka = Folkstyle Wrestling | image = Determined.jpg | imagecaption = Student works for a fall | imagesize = 220px | focus = [[Grappling]] | country = {{flagicon|USA}} [[United States]] | creator = | parenthood = [[Wrestling]] | famous_pract = Jordan Burroughs, Kyle Dake, Cael Sanderson, Isaiah Martinez. | olympic = No }} '''Scholastic wrestling''', sometimes known in the [[United States]] as '''folkstyle wrestling''', is a style of [[amateur wrestling]] practiced at the [[high school]] and [[middle school]] levels in the United States. This [[wrestling]] style is essentially [[collegiate wrestling]] with some slight modifications. It is practiced in 49 of the 50 [[U.S. state|states]] in the United States. When practiced by wrestling clubs of younger participants, scholastic wrestling is better known as "folkstyle".
According to an athletics participation survey taken by the [[National Federation of State High School Associations]], boys' wrestling ranked eighth in terms of the number of schools sponsoring teams, with 9,445 schools participating in the 2006-07 school year. Also, 257,246 boys participated in the sport during that school year, making scholastic wrestling the sixth most popular sport among high school boys. In addition, 5,048 girls participated in wrestling in 1,227 schools during the 2006-07 season.<ref>{{cite web | last = Krisher | first = Cassie | title = High School Wrestling Rules Changes Announced for 2008-09 | publisher = [[National Federation of State High School Associations|NFHS]] | date = 2008-05-01 | url = http://www.nfhs.org/web/2008/05/high_school_wrestling_rules_chan.aspx | accessdate = 2008-11-05 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080521135733/http://www.nfhs.org/web/2008/05/high_school_wrestling_rules_chan.aspx | archivedate = 2008-05-21 | df = }}</ref> Scholastic wrestling is currently practiced in 49 of the 50 states; only [[Mississippi]] does not officially sanction scholastic wrestling for high schools and middle schools. [[Arkansas]], the 49th state to sanction high school wrestling, began scholastic wrestling competition in the 2008-09 season with over forty schools participating.<ref>{{cite web | last = Seaton | first = Philip | title = High School Wrestling Debuts Around Arkansas | publisher = [[HSWrestling.net]] | date = 2008-09-28 | url = http://www.hswrestling.net/high-school-wrestling-debuts-around-arkansas/ | accessdate = 2008-11-05 }}</ref> Shortly after, [[Ocean Springs High School]] became the first school in Mississippi to have a high school team.
==History== [[File:Wrestling glenninvite002.jpg|thumb|300px|In scholastic wrestling, great emphasis is placed on one wrestler's control of the opponent on the mat, usually by controlling the opponent's legs or torso. When a wrestler maintains restraining power over an opponent, as seen here, he is said to be in the position of advantage.]]
The history of scholastic wrestling in the United States is closely tied to the development of its college counterpart. The [[Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association]] held its first tournament in 1905, which soon sparked many more wrestling tournaments for both [[college]] and [[university]] students and high school students.<ref>"Wrestling, Freestyle" by Michael B. Poliakoff from ''Encyclopedia of World Sport: From Ancient Times to the Present'', Vol. 3, p. 1191, eds. David Levinson and Karen Christensen (Santa Barbara, CA: ABC-CLIO, Inc., 1996).</ref> College and high school wrestling grew especially after the standardization of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) wrestling rules, which applied early on to both collegiate and scholastic wrestling (with high school modifications). More colleges, universities, and junior colleges began offering dual meets and tournaments, including championships and having organized wrestling seasons. There were breaks in wrestling seasons because of [[World War I]] and [[World War II]], but in the high schools especially, state association wrestling championships sprung up in different regions throughout the 1930s and 1940s. As amateur wrestling grew after World War II, various collegiate athletic conferences also increased the number and quality of their wrestling competition, with more wrestlers making the progression of wrestling in high school, being recruited, and entering collegiate competition. Girls' scholastic wrestling has somewhat fuzzy roots, as girls from time to time would join boys' teams as early as the 1970s, and there have been established various private girls wrestling clubs throughout the U.S.. Most notable among these athletes was National Wrestling Hall of Fame inductee, Tricia Saunders. However, the first official, public-school all-girls wrestling team was formed in Brookline High School in Brookline Massachusetts by coach Dustin Carter; the team of 15 girls was formed in 1993 and became an official public high school team three years later. The first official U.S. Girls Wrestling Nationals was held 1997. Today, the various state high school associations continue to also host annual wrestling championships for individuals and for teams.
